description.narrative: In April 2012, a request was received from the Government of Burkina Faso to finance a household survey (Enquête Multisectorielle Continue/Multisectoral continue survey). The main objectives of this survey are to establish a permanent system to collect data to feed main indicators for the national development strategy and MDGs. In the proposed Plan for phasing out Sweden’s development cooperation with Burkina Faso 2013-2016, pro-poor sustainable growth is one of the three sectors for Swedish support. The total of amount is SEK 15 million for two years, 2013 and 2014. Six amendments were signed on 20 May 2015, 31 August 2015, 22 December 2015, 04 August 2016, 18 January 2017 and 20 October 2017, respectively. These amendments were made to allow both the continuation of the activities which has been delayed and, secondly, the consolidation of the achievements by the preparation of the second phase of this relevant household survey.

Insatsen syftar till att stödja inrättandet av ett flexibelt och kostnadseffektivt system för regelbundna hushållsundersökningar som den nationella statistikmyndigheten i Burkina Faso (INSD) genomför. Systemet ska tillåta insamling av relevant och uppdaterad socio-ekonomisk information för att kunna följa upp genomförande och utfall av den nationella utvecklingsstrategin och milleniemålen.

The project aims to support the establishment of a flexible and cost-effective system of regular household surveys in the national statistical authority in Burkina Faso (INSD). The system should allow the collection of relevant and updated socio-economic information in order to monitor the implementation and outcomes of the national development strategy and the MDGs.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Some expected results of the Multisectoral Continuous Survey are: The main survey was conducted in 2014-2015 and these results were disseminated in 2015. In January 2016, all results were published on the INSD website and in newspapers across the country. This is a remarkable result because the results were published thirteen months later, the end of the collection (end of December 2014). The monitoring indicators for the MDGs and the country's poverty reduction strategy are permanently documented. However, it is clear that the 2014 survey provided a large number of indicators necessary for national planning and international objectives. These indicators were urgently requested by various government authorities and the INSD was also able to respond to these requests from users. The household surveys in the country are harmonized and integrated. The organization of a continuous household survey covering the whole year, at a cost that can be covered in the long term by the national budget, is a significant step forward compared to the ad hoc surveys that depending on the donor funds. The survey conducted in 2014 was a large-scale test of this concept. The enumeration area or household panel to be used for dynamic analysis is available and has been used for the current census. As expected result, the experience of the EMC has made it possible to design the Harmonized Survey on the Living Conditions of Households (EHCVM) in 2018 in the eight WAEMU member countries? The survey took place in the same period throughout WAEMU within sampled households. It was used to draw up the poverty profile of households in each country according to a modernized and harmonized methodology. It will also be the basic tool for monitoring national international agendas and policies (SDG, African Union 2063 Agenda), so that the indicators that will be produced at the end of the operation for each country will be comparable to those other countries.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
